section: i-on will maintain the operation of the Hosted Site continuously, twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week, including holidays, with the exception of reasonable hardware and software maintenance that must be performed on the Hosting Computer and/or the Hosted Site. i-on will use best efforts to schedule and perform such maintenance between the hours of 8pm and 8am Eastern Standard Time on weekdays, or during weekends.
explanation: This clause states a 24/7 uptime commitment, but then introduces an exception for 'reasonable hardware and software maintenance'. The term 'reasonable' is subjective and undefined. This ambiguity creates a loophole, potentially allowing i-on to perform maintenance during peak hours, impacting the Hosted Site's availability, without violating the 24/7 commitment. This is an in-text contradiction as the commitment and the exception lack a clear boundary.

section: 4. an emergency electrical power backup system for the Hosting Computer;
explanation: This section guarantees the provision of an emergency electrical power backup system, implying a reliable system to prevent service interruptions due to power outages. However, there are no details about the duration or capacity of this backup system, which means that the clause is ambiguous. Is it just enough to save the data or can it run for 48 hours? This type of ambiguity in legal terms makes this obligation difficult to enforce and creates a legal contradiction if the law asks for a reliable power backup system that can last up to 72 hours.

section: The Customer is solely responsible for any and all software programs, server-side scripts, and/or executable components that are installed on the Hosting Computer for the purpose of providing interactive applications or dynamic content on the Hosted Site. Any such programs, scripts, or components that might affect the stability of the Hosting Computer or interfere with other Web sites on the Hosting Computer must be approved by i-on before being installed on the Hosted Site, i-on reserves the right to deny the Customer permission to install any such programs, scripts, or components, to require additional fees for the installation and/or ongoing operation of any such programs, scripts, or components, or to remove any such programs, scripts, or components, if in i-on's sole discretion they will interfere with the operation of the Hosting Computer or exceed the Customer's monthly allocation of Web administration services.
explanation: This paragraph assigns responsibility for software installed by the Customer, but then allows i-on to approve, deny, charge fees for, or remove such software at its 'sole discretion'. This creates a potential contradiction: While the customer is responsible, i-on has overarching control, thus the responsibility is not really the customer's to bear. The discretion is also undefined and not objective; as such, i-on can decide to remove the software due to their mood.

section: The Customer acknowledges that the Internet is an unreliable, unsecured, and error-prone network and agrees to hold i-on harmless for any interruptions in service to the Hosted Site or inability for users to reach or effectively use the Hosted Site that arises outside the scope of i-on's responsibilities as explicitly described in this Agreement.
explanation: This statement attempts to absolve i-on of responsibility for Internet unreliability, but it also includes 'outside the scope of i-on's responsibilities as explicitly described in this Agreement'. This leads to a contradiction with clause 1, which guarantees an emergency electrical power backup system. It is assumed that i-on has a responsibility to maintain this backup system, but this clause would allow i-on to be harmless for any interruptions that lead to unreliability and the customer holding i-on harmless for such data loss, which in this instance, they should be responsible for.

section: The term of this Agreement for the Hosted Site shall commence upon April 1, 1999 and shall continue for a period of six (6) months, unless earlier terminated in accordance with provisions hereof. This Agreement shall automatically be renewed for one (1) or more one (1) month periods unless either the Customer or i-on gives notice to the other party of its intention not to renew the Agreement, which notice must be given not less than fifteen (15) days before the end of the respective initial or renewal term.
explanation: This clause states that the initial term is six months, but the renewal term is for 'one (1) or more one (1) month periods'. The phrase 'one or more' introduces an inconsistency. Does it mean the agreement renews for a single month each time, or can it renew for multiple months at once? This misaligned terminology leads to multiple interpretations and could lead to disputes over the agreed term. This can be fixed by changing this to 'for one (1) month periods'.

section: Either party may terminate this Agreement without cause at any time effective upon thirty (30) days' written notice. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Agreement, no termination of this Agreement for any reason whatsoever shall relieve the Customer of the obligation to pay all amounts due to i-on and to make such payments on a timely basis.
explanation: The phrase 'without cause at any time effective upon thirty (30) days' written notice' is an ambiguous statement. Termination without cause would mean they do not need to provide a reason. However, this means that a customer is required to pay i-on for amounts due to i-on even when i-on is failing to adhere to their services? This is a legal contradiction that can be disputed.
